description.text:
Another feeble box of Lucky Charms cereal? No problem, create that most excellent bowl with charms in every bite with this Charms Sifter. The holes are sized to catch most charms, you should be able to sift > 90% of them.
Please note: Diabetic supplies not included.

I've printed this on a TOM with a heated build platform, it just fits since I positioned the handle toward a corner. My print-o-matic setting are: no raft, object infill 35, layer height .32, number of shells 2 and feedrate 32.
TO USE: dump some Lucky Charms cereal in the sifter, shake side to side, dump out mostly charms then clear out any plugged holes, repeat. Be careful to hide the sifter because it may anger others.
Please note: Diabetic supplies not included.

author: AdamPyschny

description.text: This week I decided to build a full functioning bear trap based on images found on Google. I worked out in theory how the mechanism should work for the trap, and then spent hours CAD up the parts to fit together nicely with the right tolerance, so the springs and latches will work smoothly. Result? The teeth bite FAST! The only downside of printing with ABS is that the 2 side arms break after me playing with it too many times. No worries though. I've designed it the way so they can be easily replaced with new springy arms. Next lot I'll print them with rubber-like ABS. That should last me a while! Caught a finger - https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=10151863634711004 Caught a banana - https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?v=505942579476680 *UPDATE - new STL files have been uploaded with minor adjustments on tolerance and build plate arrangement.

Version 2 have been uploaded - with wider base and modified springy arms for better stability. Jaws have also been modified so they close up better.  
The screws will need some sanding to make the trigger latch rotate smoothly. The less friction at the pivot the faster the teeth bite.  
The tiny piece of springy thingie underneath the trigger plate will need to be glued at the right angle. Some adjustments required after assembling the trap.

title: Double Decker V3 200 FPV racer for 2204 motors

description.text:
Double Decker V3 200 is a mini 180/200 class FPV racing quad which is designed for ultimate flight performance on 4" propellers and 2204 motors. Main features include:
  • two decks for optimal mass distribution
  • X shaped motor positions for best balance and handling
  • motors and VTx protectors
  • FPV camera 25 degree mount
  • rigid and reinforced frame parts
  • lightweight (80 g)
  • standard size components
    • Frame's speciality is that it has two decks - in front it's tall enough to cover 32x32 mm FPV camera like Sony PZ0420. Rear part is as flat as possible so that the battery is close to the center of gravity and to the center of thrust for better flight performance. With this copter and setup below I have flown best time at kart racing spot yet: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RN-JIWSBnYY. Motors are placed in square shaped footprint so that it has better balance and handling in all axes. VTx and motors are protected by integrated bumpers. The frame also features optional motor protectors. When printed in ABS with 100% infill it's also very rigid and will survive many crashes. FPV camera plate has fixed angle of 25 degrees for speed flying. Of course, the angle can be finely tuned by placing spacers between the camera and plate. Total frame weight is about 80 grams (ABS, 100% infill, M2.5 self-tapping screws), AUW with FPV gear and 3s lipo 1000 mAh is about 340 grams. Using 4S and DAL 4045 BN propellers it features incredible power to weight ratio of about 6:1. My recommended build setup uses standard size components like 2204 motors, CC3D atom flight controller board and full size FPV camera. Rear part includes CC3D atom flight controller (without plastic cover) that is partly embedded to bottom plate. Behind FC is a place for VTX, ideally some flat one like TS5823. There is enough space for placing receiver below the FC and VTX in the lower part of the frame. The frame is also very easy to print. Recommended setup:
    motors: 4x 2204 2300kv
    ESCs: 4x Little Bee 20A (or similar size and amps)
    flight controller: CC3D Atom
    propeller: DAL 4045 BN (or similar, e.g. triblade)
    battery: 3S-4S LiPo 850-1300 mAh
    FPV camera: Sony PZ0420
    video TX: TS5823 200mW Software:
    BLHeli14.1 firmware for ESCs + Damped Light mode + Oneshot125
    Cleanflight Luxfloat controller PIDs:
    roll/pitch: 2, 0.040, 30
    yaw: 6, 0.040, 5
    looptime: 1800 Let me know how it flies for you. My intention is to design the best printable 4" FPV racing quad. Thanks and have fun!

Spacers: print attached spacers and use 12-16mm M2.5 self-tapping screws. The middle part needs two 30mm M2.5 self-tapping screws.
The bottom plate has two holes (usb connector, bottom of motor pins) so that CC3D atom flight controller can be placed as low as possible. It should be turned by 180 degrees (motor pins facing towards the front of the copter). You can use e.g. hot glue to fix the FC to the plate. On the right side of the copter there is large enough hole so you can connect USB without any problem.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A simple to use tool for understanding the components of an EKG.  
After selling these devices for the past few years, I've decided to upload it to thingiverse and allow other medical students to download and print this for free (more and more of us are building 3D printers).
I will have to update the file on thingiverse as the 3D relief of the myocardium is missing... you can always print out a picture and paste it on there if need be.
I keep this in my pocket and use it quite often - it is especially helpful when tutoring first year medical students.
I have another version with 90 segments for the circles (smoothed design) and recessed lettering, but I found this version is easier to print and make functional (it should just come off the build plate and rotate about the transverse axis freely)

author: niko83dk

description.text:
An organic dome experiment. This started as a test of some ideas related to building an organically shaped dome of CNC'd plywood. I don't have a CNC machine, or easy access to one, so I did the prototyping with my 3D printer. There was no glue used to hold the dome together when it was just a framework. (See third picture above.) After glueing rice paper to each triangle a little hot glue was used to lock each triangle into the framework.
In the next stage I'll be turning the dome into a light sculpture by covering each triangle with translucent rice paper and putting programmable LEDs underneath.
1/21/2016 Covered the triangles with rice paper. Next step is adding the programmable RGB LEDs. Should be done tomorrow!
1/22/2016 Finished the light sculpture!

This is a pulley for a Prusa i3. This will help keep the filament in a nice arc on top of the printer instead of spreading out on the spool and going everywhere. This mounts to the top of the right tower on my Prusa by HICtop, and can be mirrored to go on the other tower if you choose. Requires:
Both pieces
A small finishing nail or RC body clip
A lighter or heat gun First, print the items and use the lighter to heat up the plastic at the base of the 2 triangles. Bend them out just a little bit to get the parts to roll smoothly when the nail or body clip is inserted. Put the nail through the 2 holes and the pulley. Bend the ends of the nail up/down so the nail will not slide out. Unscrew the top tower bolt on your printer and slide the bolt through the hole on the bottom plate of the assembly. Screw the bolt back in place, and then pull your filament over the pulley. You're done!

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tired of brittle 3d printed frames that bend while banking, constantly need new spare parts and lack protection of your valuable electronics? Then try the Comet. The Comet was designed to withstand a huge amount of force on the arms whiles being even lighter than other comparable frames. The vibration damped deck is in the center of the chassis to ensure a maximum of protection for your cam and flight controller. The 250mm variant can carry 5" and 6" props (even though the 6" make it already tough to mount the lipo on the top) whilst the 280mm arms give you enough space for a huge 4s Lipo + 6" prop. Our two test frames already survived a respectable amount of beating, including a free fall on wooden floor. Please share your experience with the frame! Updates: v1.0 - 19th of April 2016

description.text: I was trying to prototype a specialized chain for carrying pieces through a workflow.  It turned out that the chain works pretty well as a printed piece.  I'm working on converting the pieces into OPENSCAD so you'd be able to print any size link and the appropriate gear.  I'm also going to be hooking it up to an arduino, touchosc, processing combination to make something for the kids to play with (watch for details).

Using the Up! printer with solid fill and fine resolution you should get pretty good results. I've found that you should print at least two of each link (in order to allow a layer to cool). Some of the dimensions (OD and ID are .75 mm and 8.25 mm, so I think you'd have pretty poor results if you used anything except fine resolution.

description.text:
This set of files is for a spool management system. The included image is somewhat self explanatory. Items needed in addition to the printed parts are two M8 rods 100 mm long, three 608 bearings, an M8 hook or loop and some various M8 nuts and small washers. The point of the device is so that the spool can be hung and will be free to rotate as well as un-spool. This should prevent any twisting torsion on the filament. It is necessary to have some sort of anchor point(s) in the ceiling to string the device up to. Ideally two anchor points should be used so that the hanging string will not twist, and instead the 608 bearing will allow free rotation.  
The openscad files are included, and they are parametric wherever i thought to do so. In particular, if I were making this device again, I would reduce the height of the "rotator" unit as well as the spool holders. Having printed it, I can see that I used an unnecessary amount of PLA. The spool holder diameter can also be changed to suit the size of spool that is typically used.  
This device is not inspired from anything that comes to mind. The idea is not terribly original, and i am sure there are dozens of similar objects on Thingiverse. It's my first project though!

See the pictures. The spool holders need the bearings to be hammered or pressed in. The spool holders are then pressed into the spool holes. A 100 mm threaded rod is passed through the bearing holes and a washer is added on each side. Then the legs are added on either side. The rotation piece is then threaded onto the second 100 mm rod. When it is located in the middle, it can be secured using nuts and washers (use four). The rotation unit/rod combo is then threaded onto the legs and secured with more nuts and washers. Finally the hook is passed through the rotation unit and then through a bearing. Finally a nut and washer is added and the whole is suspended from two lines from the ceiling above the printer. A picture is worth a thousand words. Consult the images.

Not as clean as most Han's on Thingiverse. The cleaner versions also forgot to place any kind of textures on the face of the liquid bath? There would be some sort of sloshy-ness, right? description.text: This clamp allows for rigid coupling to a bowden style extruder assembly center of gravity at the point of most mass (Nema 17 stepper motor) as well as interconnection points to produce elastic constraints to a rigid frame. The clamp is flexible and has compliant elements so it should be able to slip on a variety of Nema 17 motor exterior dimension when affected by manufacturing tolerances. This is useful to reduce both delta carriage effector weight (in the case of a direct drive extrusion system) while also reducing the length of the bowden conduit tube (to reduce load on motor, binding, hysteresis of pressure on filament being extruded). Hardware is 1 x M3 nut and 1 x M3 x 25mm socket head cap screw. This design is a derivative of the concepts embodied in this design hosted elsewhere: http://repables.com/r/531/ So far works well even with 1.75mm filament. Cut your bowden tube to the size needed for the bot's range of motion. Source CAD attached. Enjoy.

comments.text: I've been using Glenn's original hanging "air-struder" for a few years now, and it's a great improvement.
comments.author: jimustanguitar

comments.text: Thanks for the comments, and the tip!   I am late coming back to the delta 3D printing game (still rocking the spectra line), but the air-struder design and spinoff concepts of mostly decoupling the extruder inertia from the kinematics of the effector are a brilliant idea.  I am going to do some more research on whether it is better (for my machine setup) to couple the flying extruder to the travelling z carriages vs fixed positions on the top of the rigid frame.  What I like most about the coupling to the traveling z carriages is that there is a predictable support throughout the duration of print as the model increases in height.  In the case of my support to the top of the frame I get variable tension transmitted to the pulleys as the model increases in z.  On the other hand, the magnitude of that load is not as high as supporting the entire weight of the extruder assembly alone (as is the case for mounting to the z carriages).  I'll need to see if my z carriages and bearings have a tight enough grip to support the extra load...it might even help!

description.text:
The original stl files for this (and all other ULA rockets) can be found on the web at the following URL: http://www.ulalaunch.com/3d.aspx This is a remix of the ULA Atlas V 551 model. I took the original solid model and made a number of modifications, including:
  • I separated the stand from the rocket. I added two posts to fit inside the two central core rocket nozzles.
  • I broke the entire length of the rocket into four pieces, numbered 1 (bottom) to 4 (top). This will allow printing to larger scales (e.g., 1:100).
  • I added holes for connecting pegs. This model requires three connecting pegs.
    • I plan a future modification of making as much the model hollow as possible. [Done. -KD] This will decrease print time and required material. [Maybe, maybe not. -KD] I'm still printing my initial test item, so please stand by until I can get photos of this initial print posted here. If this works, I'll try printing this model at 1:100 scale... [Done, see Update #4. -KD] [UPDATE #1] I ran into a miswound filament issue on my first test print of this model, so I won't have any pics of it until tomorrow night, assuming all goes well with my second attempt. I realized with my initial attempt that the first piece should be printed with the nozzles upward... I always seem to forget that! I also found an issue with the depth of the peg hole in the bottom of piece 2, so I fixed that in my stl files and will upload them tomorrow... [UPDATE #2] My second attempt at the print (in black PLA) ended in disaster! :-( Sorry for the delay... I'll try again, maybe at a smaller scale (with a shorter print time), soon... sorry for the delay. [UPDATE #3] I've modified the model a little bit, hollowing out the body pieces (although I'm beginning to doubt that this saves any print time...) and I'll try printing it AGAIN this evening... at a bit smaller scale... again. please stand by! [UPDATE #4] Success! Finally! The model turned out not badly. I think there are some locations where the top of the five strap-on boosters meet with the central core, where the inner hole (for the connecting peg) breaks with the surface of the model. It doesn't actually look very conspicuous, but I could fix this by moving the peg hole down in both the bottom of piece #2 and the top of piece #1. I've deleted the previous stl files and uploaded the most recent ones. These differ from the previous files in that the bodies are a bit hollowed out, whereas the previous files had fully solid bodies. I'm beginning to wonder if this actually reduces the print time or not...

  • To print this at 1:100 scale, the total model height should be 64cm. I made each of the rocket body pieces to be of equal height, so they should each be 16cm at this scale.

description.text:
So I liked the combination of JSC's sliding holder using a rubberband, and the one that uses an adjustment screw. This one uses a spring available in a kit from Home Depot for about $4.50USD I used his Fusion 360 file from the one that uses an adjustment knob, lost the knob, and added back in the ability for a spring. I also resized the sliding part so that it moves freely inside of the base, and the arms that hold the phone to hold thicker phones, and phones with cases, this will hold anything from a Moto E to a Nexus 6 or I phone 6 Plus.
I will upload videos of assembly, and use when I print some more, holders, and pick up some more springs. I will also note the proper spring used, when I purchase new ones.

Installing the spring in the slide. To install the spring, i used a piece of the core of a paracord, looped it through the loop in the spring, then ran the cord through the slide, from the bottom to the top. Once the loop is sticking out, stick a 1/4 20bolt in the hole, then work the loop of the spring that is sticking out the top around the head of the bolt, the spring will naturally slip under the head of the screw. This is what more or less permanently secures the spring to the bolt. The tension of the loop wanting to lift locks it in place. Installing the spring in the base, and the 1/4 20 nut in the base. Repeat the paracord process from the slide, the spring will stretch as you pull the loop through the bottom hole. This is fine. When the spring comes through, I stretched approximately 4-5 loops through. On one of my prints the nut slipped right in beside the spring wire. On the other I had to ever so slightly heat the nut. this can be done by using a lighter, or a torch. I stuck a 1/4 20 bolt in the nut in order to hold it, and not touch the hot nut, both while heating and inserting it in the print. I just slowly passed the nut back and forth through a propane torch on low. You do not want the nut any where near hot, just warm. Pass it through the flame a few times and try to insert it. If it does not go pass through the flame a few more times, and repeat. The nut should press in with resistance, if it slides in easily the spring will most likely push it into your plastic, and it will not work.
If done properly this will trap the spring as well as insert the nut securely.
This sounds overly complicated, but it is not. Once the nut is in place, if it is to warm grab an icecube or run some cool water over it to rapidly cool it down before damaging your print. Then trim the spring off. on one of mine i used a pair of micro side cutters, on the other i used just a regular pair of side cutters. The regular side cutters leave a little bit of wire sticking out, which may not be kid friendly, however it provides some tension on my tripod and removes any slight wiggle.

title: Cable Chain Anchors for The Lulzbot Taz Openbuilds X and Z Axis

description.text:
This project contains the Cable chain anchors for the X and Z axis Openbuilds retrofits I created for the Lulzbot TAZ series of printers. Unlike the Y axis pieces(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1145951) , these units are highly specific to that set of modifications, and you will need at least the Openbuilds X axis mod installed to utilize these correctly. I also included a set of Igus block mount ends, because I had a set of cable chains that didn't come with them. The X axis chain uses an Igus 10 x 15mm cable chain with end mounts (I specifically used these cable chains: http://www.ebay.com/itm/261848758125?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT ) The Z frame to X midpoint run is a larger 15x20mm cable chain. I used an Igus one i bought for another project a few years back, so i don't have a part number for that one, but you should be able to make most of them fit. You will need 6 M3 heat set inserts
( http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/119/3267/=zw8u0v) , 8 10mm M3 bolts, Two 42mm-ish long M5 bolts to replace two of the shorter bolts found on the X motor mount backplate (where the Midpoint mount attaches) and 2 shorter M5 10mm long cap screws and T-slot Nuts (drop in nuts work well here). Also, Many zip ties.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle

Infill:

85% or better

Notes: None of these parts should require support to print

Instructions: To use this, you will most likely need to extend your wireing harness. Know that going in before you proceed, Insert the heat set inserts into the mounting tabs where the cable chains will mount. To start, remove the Split Wire Loom outer protective hard plastic jacket from your primary and if present, secondary extruder cables. You will reuse pieces of this, so do not discard.
Attach 1 section of the 15 x 20mm cable chain to the "Openrails_Z_frame_Cable_Chain_End_3_0_a.stl" part using two of the M3 screws, and secure that to the frame next to the control box with the T slot nuts and shorter M5 bolts. Route your cables into the cable chain (I highly reccommend the ones with the removable sections door, makes this part easier) and attach the other end to the Upper tab of the "Openrails_Z_to_X_Cable_Chain-Midpoint_transition_7_0_c" part using 2 more M3 screws.
Next route the remaining cable through a section of 10 x 15 cable chain, and mount one end to the underside of the far midpoint mounting tab using 2 M3 bolts. For the last mount, you will need to pull the extruder carriage, extruder carriage mount plate, and possibly the backplate and top spacer bolt. You may need longer bolts. Attach the "Openrails_X_Carriage_Cable_Chain_End_5_0_c" to the backplate using the X axis belt anchors and top spacer bolt as anchor points. You may need longer bolts for this step. Reassemble the X carriage and then attach the remaining end of the X axis cable chain to the end mount. Next, attach split loom jacket sections to any wires that look exposed, to taste. This is asthetic, not required. Now route the primary and optionally the secondary extruder cables up to their normal mounting locations. Use zip ties to secure the cables to the middle of the and two side tabs of the X carriage cable chain mount at the provided locations, and replace the zip ties at the top of the X extruder carraige mount plate. Refer to the pictures for proper placement of anything.

This project is intended to build up a library of landforms that can be used for teaching earth science. I'm using Terrain2STL by Thatcher Chamberlin. This easy to use app uses converts terrain from Google Maps into STL files. The files were then cleaned up and modified in Meshmixer and Tinkercad. Models are not all to the same scale. More attractive models can be printed by expanding the z-axis by 2X, if you don't mind the distortion. http://jthatch.com/terrain2stl/
NGSS

This project is intended to build up a library of landforms that can be used for teaching earth science. I'm using Terrain2STL by Thatcher Chamberlin. This easy to use app uses converts terrain from Google Maps into STL files. The files were then cleaned up and modified in Meshmixer and Tinkercad. Models are not all to the same scale. More attractive models can be printed by expanding the z-axis by 2X, if you don't mind the distortion. http://jthatch.com/terrain2stl/

• Choose a landform that you want to print. Terrain2STL can't print terrain at high northern and southern latitudes (Norway, for example). It also won't work well on small landforms (Devil's Tower, for example). You will get the best results with terrain with a lot of relief, such as mountains.

  • Go to Terrain2STL http://jthatch.com/terrain2stl/ and find the landform. Switch to Satellite view to see the terrain. Terrain2STL doesn't have a search function so it might be helpful to have Google Maps open to help you find landmarks.

  • Click on Center to View to open a red box that outlines the area that will be turned into a printable STL file. Use the Box Size slider to adjust the box size so that it will cover the entire piece of terrain you want to print. Click and drag the box into position covering the target terrain.

  • Click on Create STL File and then Download to download the STL file of the terrain. The file name will be the latitude and longitude of the terrain.

  • Open Meshmixer and import the STL file. Use Edit --> Make Solid to close up any holes and Edit --> Plane Cut to trim off extra parts around and under the landform

  • Export the file as an STL file and load in your slicer software, such as Cura. Usually your landform will look better if you stretch the height (z-direction) by 1.5X or 2X. This can also reveal subtle details that would otherwise be missed.

Glaciated Terrain
  • Matterhorn - excellent example of a horn, in Swiss Alps
  • U-Shaped Valley - shows glacial erosion, from Glacier National Park in Montana
  • Garden Wall Arete - Glacier National Park in Montana
  • Electric Peak cirque - Gallatin range in Montana
    • Miscellaneous
  • Uluru / Ayers Rock - sandstone landmark in Australia
  • Sugar Loaf - granite mountain near Rio de Janiero, Brazil
  • Denali - highest peak in US, formerly Mt. McKinley
  • Table Mountain - plateau near Cape Town, South Africa
  • Meteor Crater - also known as Barrington Crater, meteorite impact crater in Arizona
  • Green River - nice example of meandering river and oxbow in Utah
  • Marakei Atoll - coral atoll in Pacific
  • Wake Island Atoll - coral atoll in Pacific
  • Grand Teton - fault block mountain in Wyoming
    • Volcanoes
  • Mauna Kea - Hawaiian shield volcano
  • Mauna Loa - Hawaiian shield volcano
  • Mt. St. Helens - stratovalcano in Washington, erupted in 1980, post eruption recovery of ecosystem has been extensively studied
  • Mayon - "perfect cone" stratovalcano in Philippines
  • Mt. Fuji - stratovolcano, beloved symbol of Japan
  • Mt. Etna - very active stratovolcano in Sicily
  • Vesuvius - stratovolcano, buried Pompeii in AD 79
  • Paricutin - dormant cinder cone in Mexico, famous for rapid and well documented rise in a corn field in 1943
  • Mt Shasta - stratovolcano in Northern California
  • Nevado del Ruiz - stratovolcano in Colombia
  • Pinatubo - active stratovolcano in Philippines, massive eruption in 1991
  • Thera / Santorini - caldera in Mediterranean, remains of Thera eruption blamed for fall of Minoan civilization
  • Tambora - active stratovolcano in Indonesia, massive eruption in 1815 blamed for causing "year without a summer."
  • Arenal - active stratovolcano in Costa Rica
  • Kilimanjaro - dormant stratovolcano in Tanzania
  • Popocatepetl - active stratovolcano in Mexico
  • Krakatoa - remains of massive 1883 eruption
  • Pelee - active stratovolcano on island of Martinique, deadly eruption in 1902
  • Mt. Rainier - active stratovolcano in Washington, could bury Seattle in mud if it erupts
  • Crater Lake - caldera lake in Oregon
  • Montserrat - Caribbean island, home to Soufriere Hills volcano, subject of excellent crisis management lesson plan http://www.juicygeography.co.uk/montserrat.htm
  • Cotopaxi - active stratovolcano in Ecuador
  • Mount Merapi - active stratovolcano in Indonesia
  • Diamond Head - Oahu, Hawaii
  • Pitons - Saint Lucia, volcanic plugs (necks)

Objective This project is intended to create 3D models of landforms for use in the earth science classroom. Models can be used as examples during instruction. They can also be used for assessment. For example show a student a landform and ask them to explain how it might have been formed. Audience This project was made for use in middle school (grades 6 - 8), but could be useful for all ages. Preparation This project uses the free web based app Terrain2STL and the free downloadable program Meshmixer.
http://jthatch.com/terrain2stl/
http://www.meshmixer.com/ You can use Tinkercad instead of Meshmixer, but that requires a bit more work to get printable models. The method using Tinkercad is expained here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1316498 Steps

  • Choose a landform that you want to print. Terrain2STL can't print terrain at high northern and southern latitudes (Norway, for example). It also won't work well on small landforms (Devil's Tower, for example). You will get the best results with terrain with a lot of relief, such as mountains.

  • Go to Terrain2STL http://jthatch.com/terrain2stl/ and find the landform. Switch to Satellite view to see the terrain. Terrain2STL doesn't have a search function so it might be helpful to have Google Maps open to help you find landmarks.

  • Click on Center to View to open a red box that outlines the area that will be turned into a printable STL file. Use the Box Size slider to adjust the box size so that it will cover the entire piece of terrain you want to print. Click and drag the box into position covering the target terrain.

  • Click on Create STL File and then Download to download the STL file of the terrain. The file name will be the latitude and longitude of the terrain.

  • Open Meshmixer and import the STL file. Use Edit --> Make Solid to close up any holes and Edit --> Plane Cut to trim off extra parts around and under the landform

  • Export the file as an STL file and load in your slicer software, such as Cura. Usually your landform will look better if you stretch the height (z-direction) by 1.5X or 2X. This can also reveal subtle details that would otherwise be missed.
    • Results Completed models are included here.

UPDATE 1.2 (10/12/17) Top and bottom case has been update. Replaced standoff "nubs" with mounting holes. Mounting holes updated to 2.6mm diameter (works with M2.5 x 5mm screws). Holder updated to better house slide switch. UPDATE 1.1 The case has been updated! Added new switch holder. New lip snap fits halves together, so no need for news! Removed screws holes for amp, Pi 2 and powerboost, just snap fit onto nubs! Added washers to prevent screws from puncturing case. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xzfvlyLVFtw Full Parts List & Tutorial:
https://learn.adafruit.com/pigrrl-2/overview Download Fusion 360 FREE
http://autode.sk/1Ro3wkb PiGRRL Gamepad PCB on Oshpark
https://oshpark.com/shared_projects/i2TaIEic Raspberry Pi Retro Game Console
This project takes the original concept of the PiGRRL and makes it more powerful, using a Raspberry Pi 2 (or Model B+). It's about the same size but features more buttons (D-Pad, A,B,X,Y, L, R, pause and start.) and four extra buttons on the PiTFT. It's sporting a small audio amplifier and speaker, so you can enjoy the crispy sounds of 8-bit goodness. Easier to build!
With this update, we really wanted to make it easier to build. We've dramatically cut the build time in half by making a custom gamepad PCB. Just solder in the buttons and an IDC box header to the gamepad PCB - No more tedious button wiring! Project Expectations
This project is geared towards beginners, but is still a big project to take on. This guide will walk you through all the necessary steps to wire, assemble and build your very first Raspberry Pi game console. It does require a good amount of soldering, wire tinning and good ol' elbow grease, but don't be discouraged! If your dedicated to take on this project, it'll only take a weekend to make.

description.text: I got myself a 3dFly kit from hovership, (http://shop.hovership.com/3dfly-micro-quad-kit/) after several design attempts and models found here on thingyverse I think I've landed on one I like enough to share. It is similar in design to other out there but as usual i wanted to do it myself in sketchup so I could modify things to my hearts content. The frame it self is very simple but robust with high walls around the FC to keep out water (Oregon), I have not managed to break it. I used three vibration dampeners (https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=40613) to suspend the lower section containing the FC. I soldered a led into pwm 7 and hot glued it to the flat bit on the rear of the lower section. The FC is also secured to its mounts using hot glue. To keep the motors from moving I used 4 zipties to pinch them in place. I also recommend using some heat shrink to cover the bottom end of the motors (it will save you money if you plan to keep things flying). I'm slowly collecting micro fpv gear and a fpv version is coming as well. https://youtu.be/qeqgpXViA1M

title: Half of a spool holder that uses 608zz bearings

description.text:
Yes, it's yet another spool holder based on 608zz skate bearings! This one requires extra hardware (besides the bearings), but is also adjustable to variable spool widths. You will need:
  • 2× this part
  • 2× 8×100 mm threaded rods
  • 4× or 8× 8mm nuts
  • 4× 608zz skate bearings
  • A wrench or nut driver
  • A spool you want to mount on the roller
    • (You might also try 5/16-inch rods/bolts and nuts instead of the 8mm rods and nuts. The inch size is slightly smaller, but way cheaper in the US. Note that whichever one you use, they must match: 5/16-inch bolts won't work with 8mm nuts, nor vice versa.)

Assembly instructions This part holds two 608zz bearings. You'll need two of this part; the threaded rods keep the two pieces together, and are the axles for the bearings. The nuts keep this part from sliding out of the appropriate distance.
  • Put a bearing into one of the receptacles.
  • Push the threaded rod through the pair of holes. There's some clearance below the bearing, so you'll need to move the bearing around until its bore lines up with the other holes and the threaded rod. Once the rod is through it, the bearing will not shift.
  • Put a nut onto one end of the threaded rod. This will be an outer nut on that side.
  • (Optional) Put a nut onto the inner side as well. This makes adjustment more difficult, but also reduces the chance of the two pieces accidentally getting nudged closer to each other, derailing the spool.
  • Repeat steps 1–4 for the other receptacle on the same piece.
  • (Optional) If you placed inner nuts, add two more—one on each rod. These will be the inner nuts for the other piece.
  • Put the bearings into the other piece.
  • Carefully push that piece onto the two threaded rods.
  • Place the outer nuts on the other piece.
  • Adjust nuts until the pieces are the correct width apart at both ends. It's easiest to do this directly in front of a spool so that you can visually match the spool's width to the width of the spool roller.

author: acvigue

description.text:
Playmo school bus = hours of fun for your kid!
It seats 12 kids and a driver (preferably an adult). I made it using TinkerCAD for my kid's 4yo Bday.
I doesn't show too much on the pics, but it warped a bit. I think my Rep2 is due for some TLC.
If you want to play with the model, here's the link: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1V3C2eRo4W8 How-to :
I used small nails for the wheels.
The seats are printed separately and glued to the body.
I've included 3 versions of the body:
  • normal blank one (without seats)
  • printer friendly version with supports in the windows (so you can print without supports)
  • normal with seats included (without supports)
    • Things that could be improved :
  • I figured out (too late) that not all Playmos have the same size and I have to say the fit is a bit tight... So it would be cool to add a few mills here and there.
  • take-off roof?
  • adding a door?
  • adding a steering wheel?

comments.text: Too bad my kids are now too old for Playmobil... They used to spend hours. This is great!

author: gmadurov

title: Gen6 (pre-deluxe) heat bead support w/ ATX power supply

description.text:
Figured I would share this on here, seeing what this site is all about.
I also want to preface that I'm sure people can do this in their sleep, but I had a heck of a time finding an easy way to do this, and I figured I would share my set up.
Also, the files are just an HTML file of the instruable, along with the image posted above. This project is to be used to control the heat bed of any 3D printer running Gen6, however, it can be used to run any 3D printer heat bed that can be properly powered with an ATX. This setup uses an ATX power supply, which also powers the Gen6 board. If you don't have an ATX power supply, it will be easy to implement one into a gen6 printer, or you could replace it with some other 12v power supply. The bread and butter of this is the PID heat controller. The markdown hates me, so have some raw link text to the one I used.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/161040584256?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1439.l2649 The PID needs 110v to it, which I used from the ATX (just got some aptly rated wire from the ATX plug to it's input) to run. I then snagged a pair of the 12v/GND wires from the ATX to the heating switch, which also was in circuit with the heat bed. And, of course, the sensor from the PID is stuck on the bottom of the heatbed. If something here wasn't clear enough (which, I won't blame you, I suck at tuts) check out the instructable I have posted. And, again, enjoy the raw (pun intended) power of the link
http://www.instructables.com/id/Heatbed-temperature-controller-for-RepRap-using-Ge/ If you still need something, feel free to comment on this or the instructable page, or even private message me through either. Thanks for checking this out!

Again, this is a fairly straight forward build. But to try and add a more step-by-step flow: 1)Acquire parts: PID controller w/ temp prob, power supply (ATX is recommanded, but you can use whatever will power your PID and heatbed) 2)Cut wires/Add wires: you can either cut off the plug ends for the ATX, and wire directly to the PID and heatbed, or buy new plugs and wire from the plugs. Either will work 3)Wire according to the PID controller: Your PID controller will come with a wire diagram. Hook the heatbed up the relay, the power up to the power, and the temperature probe to the temp probe hookups. 4)Test: Before you print, TEST IT. And test it in a safe place! If you can, test it on a strip with it's own fuse, so you don't pop your own breakers/break home fuses. Let it sit for a while, and keep a very close eye on it. I let mine site for 16 hours before I used it.

author: lionhardht

description.text:
This is a printable variant of the Derby Worx Axle Bender tool for bending pinewood derby axles (nails). It prints in 3 parts and is assembled using #4 bolts - 1 to hold the two main pieces together, and another 2 to hold the clamp piece down for securing the nail.
To make the bending easier, I recommend inserting the nail then cutting about 1/3 through using a metal hack saw.
You can put another bolt through the main two pieces as a stopper, like the Derby Worx tool, but I didn't find that to be necessary. It seems to bend consistently around 2.5 degrees without the stopper.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3 mm

Infill:

50%+

Notes: I printed at .3mm layer height and 50% infill, just for strength, and it seemed to be fine.
Depending on the bolt size, you'll probably have to drill out the holes. I used #10 bolts to assemble, and a quick drilling afterwards worked just fine.

Parametric, and surprisingly ergonomic. Serves three purposes for me:
  • Learn OpenSCAD
  • Refamiliarize myself with basic modeling in blender.
  • Lock nuts.

Pick out a wrench and print it, or modify grip_wrench.scad to make your own! If you choose to adjust your own, download "grip_wrench.scad", "corner_bit.stl", "long_bit.stl", and "short_bit.stl". Otherwise, download a prebuilt wrench's stl. Prebuilt wrenches:
  • "imperial wrench" has six different common imperial wrench sizes.
  • "reprap wrench" is a mix of metric and imperial sizes, intended to be useful for building mendel prusa repraps.
  • "metric wrench" ... doesn't exist, because I don't have metric tools handy to use as a reference!
  • "half inch wrench" has the same parameters as my original concept, and so it has two half inch notches and that's it.
  • "ham hands" is the same as "imperial wrench", but with a larger opening.
    • Note: the notch sizes on "reprap wrench" might be wrong. The opening in the wrenches is adjustable, as are all of the slots! The wrenches I compiled have an opening of 2.25cm by 8cm opening for your hand, with the exception of the "ham_hands" wrench, which is sized for someone with gynormous hands.

remixed_from.author: coricoco
remixed_from.title: Prusa I3 Extruder (Flexible Filament)(Mk7/MK8)(BLTouch/18mm Capacitive Sensor/12mm Inductive Sensor))

title: Unified Prusa i3 Extruder for Mk8 drive gear, e3d v6 hotend, and BLTouch sensor.

description.text:
I remixed the great extruder design by coricoco (thing #755164) and applied some design improvement from Marck80's remix (thing #932386). This design has numerous advantages.
  • The solid and unified design requires minimal assembly.
  • No Bowden.
  • Minimal footprint, so it does not cannibalize printing volume.
  • The center of weight is on the X axis.
  • Capable of Flexible filaments.
  • This design is backward compatible. You might able to use various accessories from the previous designs (#755164 and #932386).
    • This extruder is for Mk8 drive gear (effective diameter 7mm) and an E3Dv6 nozzle.
    Also, it equips BLTouch auto leveling sensor mount ( https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bltouch-auto-leveling-sensor-for-3d-printers ).

• PTFE tube (o.d 4mm / i.d 2mm)
  • M3*7mm countersunk bolts (x4)
  • M3*5mm bolts (x2)
  • M3*20mm bolt (x2)
  • M3*25mm bolt (x1)
  • M3*50mm bolts (x2)
  • M4*40mm bolts (x4)
  • M3 & M4 Nyloc nuts
  • Washers
  • Springs x2 (about 15mm)
  • 3mm&4mm drills
  • M3 Tap
  • 623 or 624 bearing 1ea
  • Mk8 drive gear
  • E3Dv6 hotend (or lite ver.)
  • NEMA17 & 31mm stepper motor.
  • (Optional) BLTouch sensor

I recommend using high infill rate (above 40%) and 3 perimeters. I used ABS but PLA probably works fine. Reorient parts if required.
  • Print [Extruder_mk8]. It's designed to be printed without raft and supports, however, choose decent bed adhesion option if needed.
  • Print [Extruder_fixer]. If you want to use BLTouch sensor, print the _BLTouch ver. Otherwise, print the _normal version.
  • Print [Extruder_tensioner] for your bearing size.
  • Print [Spacer] and [TubeClamp].

For better vibration resistance. use Nyloc nuts for every possible place.
  • Remove the pre-designed supports.
  • Clean the holes using drills.
  • Tap two M3 threads at the center of the extruder.
  • Test mount an E3D nozzle. Cut the PTFE tube to be placed just below the drive gear.
  • Mount a stepper motor using M3*7mm countersunk bolts
  • Mount a bearing to the [Extruder_tensioner]. For 623 bearing, use M3x20mm bolt. For 624 bearing, use M4x25mm bolt. If you're using 624 bearing, place the bolt head toward the stepper.
  • Mount the [Extruder_tensioner] assembly to the extruder body. Use M3*25mm bolt and add some washers for clearance. Tightening the bolt is tricky here. Use a long-nose plier to fix a nut. Make sure the tensioner is moving freely.
  • Mount the Mk8 drive gear to the stepper.
  • Using two M3*50mm bolts, springs, and nut, push the bearing against the drive gear. Refer the picture.
  • Place four M4 Nyloc nuts to the extruder body. Apply a drop of super glue to avoid falloff during assembly.
  • Using [Extruder_fixer] and two M3x20mm bolts, mount the E3Dv6 hotend.
  • If your hotend has PTFE tube clamp, just go to next step. Otherwise, clamp the PTFE tube using TubeClamp part & two M3*5mm bolts.
  • (Optional) Mount the BLTouch sensor. The X-offset between the nozzle and sensor probe is 23mm. Y-offset is zero. Z-offset is required to be calibrated for your parts.
  • Mount the extruder assembly to the carriage using four M4*40mm bolts. Sandwich [Spacer] between them.
  • If you have some rubbery material, place it between the stepper motor and carriage. This will greatly reduce the vibration during print.

title: Wider Light Bars and Brackets for Taz or other Large Bed Printers

description.text: This is a larger set of light bars for use with a large format printer such as a TAZ. You will need a 300mm x 300mm bed to print the strips. There is a recess on either side to allow for solder points and heat shrink as needed, with the cap fitting over the wires. I reccommend also using a layer of transparent Scotch 3m Gift wrap tape over the LED's as well (http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_EU/ScotchGift/Wrapping/Products/GiftWrapTape/)

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.5mm nozzle

Infill:

85%

Notes: Nothing should require supports. There is a bit of bridging on the endcaps.

Instructions A complete Light bar consists of a Lightstrip, 2 ends, 2 end caps, and one middle assembly. Drill out the tiny hole in the end of one end cap to allow wires to pass through. Print the parts as normal, then assemble your LED adhesive strip (make sure to get the "waterproof" ones - Not because of any supposed water resistance, but because of the protective layer over the LED's). Attach that to the main lightstrip, then coat it with a layer of gift wrap tape, making sure tocover both edges of the LED and the plastic strip. This will prevent any sagging. The Middle bracket can then go into the recessed slot. it is a pressure fit, so it should be fairly snug, You may hear a click as it goes past the narrow point. Now you can feed the wires through the endcap and press it and the wireless one on the other side in place, and fit the end pieces. The end pieces have a recess to route the wire back to the frame away from the strip for a cleaner installation. Next, snap the three frame clips into the T slot extrusion channel and you should be done except for attaching the wires!

author: Wilkoski13

title: Customizable replacement clip for folding shopping cart

description.text:
We have a folding shopping cart which is great, but the original clip was lost (and found, several times, except the last).  After loosing it for good, we used string, wire ties, whatever.  Very annoying. So I made a simple replacement.  
This type of cart seems to be very popular, sold by various manufacturers in various sizes (we got ours from Amazon) but it's basically the same cart, so this might be useful to others.

Depending on the size of your model, you'll probably want to adjust the clip length.  All dimensions are in mm.  I'm guessing the wire diameter is the same for all carts, but you may want to check.  Also, depending on your slicer and extrusion width, you may want to fine-tune the clip width.  
Print the STL in the given orientation for strength (do not print flat on it's back, it will likely delaminate under stress).  Depending on your printer calibration, you may need to do some minor filing.  
The default parameters (and sample STL) make one side much tighter than the other (so it stays on and doesn't get lost as often as the original, hopefully).  In the pictures I simply marked the looser end with a label printer.

OK, My son (12) and I are working on a vacuum forming system from scratch.  I'm pretty excited about it and want to put it out as a work in progress.  We will post the final plans and files along with a list of do's and don'ts once we are making super cool armor and injection molds for weapons.
We have a few designs we have been working on.  One included the vacuum inside of the vacuum cavity.  For that, we had the original Switch Housing.   For that, we expected the wires to pass through the body of the former. We have decided to keep the vac outside of the former (So we can upgrade as we go) so we created the Ext Switch Housing 2 file.
We also have some pretty simple feet, but our former is going to be 4' long, so we may add a secondary (middle) foot design to make sure it stays level.
The main cavity of the former still has wet glue, and the first feet are on the printer as i type.  I'll have more pics and (Hopefully) some super cool armor or something soon.
I'd love to hear from anyone who has done this in the past so we can learn from past mistakes and nail this the first time.

title: Safety 1st Ultrasonic 360 ih282 Humidifier Nozzle Replacement

description.text:
I was dismayed that our brand-new cheap little humidifier was missing its nozzle, right out of the box. Without a means to direct the stream, water vapor was rolling down and puddling.
It was quicker to throw together an ultra-crude but very effective replacement, rather than return to the store. I've undersized it deliberately by a millimeter in diameter to make room for Teflon tape but you can just ignore that and scale it up appropriately, don't worry about distorting anything.
It's messy inside but nothing that interferes with function, and it prints very fast with no supports. Let me know if there's a problem and I'll rework it.
Fits a Safety 1st Ultrasonic 360 Humidifier.

author: Wilkoski13

title: Adjustable Z endstop with cable guide

description.text:
This is a derivation of kwixson Adjustable Z endstop.
I've added a small protrusion with a 4mm hole which is designed to provide a tie point for the electrical wiring for the x-axis motor and associated endstop. The tie point isolates movement of the electrical wiring away from where it connects to the motor and endstop. This protects the electrical wiring at the key points where it joins the motor and endstop. I had a further need of this isolation than a standard Prusa might, as I have added electrical quick disconnect points for each of my motors and endstops (in order to make maintenance simpler).

Follow the build/install instructions as per http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11341. I actually used glue to attached the object as I found just using the M3 bolt didn't make it as stable as I would like.
I would also suggest that you make certain that the z endstop touches the very centre of the disc to make adjustments more consistent. Using a cable tie bind the electrical wiring to the protrusion using the small hole in the protrusion which is designed to accommodate the cable tie.

title: Meanwell NES-50 cover with Banana sockets, C14 socket, fuse, switch

description.text:
This is to attach to a Meanwell NES-50 or similar power supply with the same dimensions.
http://www.meanwell.com/mw_search/NES-50/NES-50-spec.pdf There are two components - Rear feet, and the main housing/cover. The rear feet simply screw onto the underside with a pair of M3 short bolts. The top cover is also retained with two short M3 bolts, one into the bottom, and the other into the Right side (assuming you're looking at the terminals end-on). It has provision for 2 Banana sockets with an 8.5mm diameter mounting hole.
http://www.jaycar.com.au/Interconnect/Plugs%2C-Sockets-%26-Adaptors/Banana/Red-4mm-PANEL-MOUNT-Socket/p/PS0406 There is also a hole to insert a screwdriver to adjust the voltage if you need to without taking the cover off. It also has a square hole designed for the seemingly common combo of a C14 socket, fuse, and switch as available both on ebay and at your local electronics shop:
http://www.jaycar.com.au/Power-Products-Electrical/Distribution-%26-Interconnect/Moulded-Leads/IEC-Fuse-Chassis-Male-Power-Plug-with-Switch/p/PP4003

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: I recommend 100% infill, and also ensuring that your shell thickness is 1.5mm.
The walls are 3mm thick. This means your printer won't spent 10 hours on stupid little zigzaggy infill like mine is still doing right now. Also worth noting there is a large horizontal bridge of 47mm for the hole for the switch. I found with my printer set for 60mm/s and 0.2mm layer thickness, I had no problem. YMMV. I suggest doing a bridge test and see how your printer will go with that distance before committing to the print. No support should be necessary. Once my print finishes, I'll upload a photo.

Assembly should be as straight forward as wiring up your switch/socket/fuse, banana plugs etc and putting it together. Use long enough wires so you can screw onto the terminals on the PSU as the last step, but not so long as you'll have a hard time putting it together. I would also suggest leaving the switch/socket/fuse module un-clipped while you push the PSU into the cover so you can use that hole to make sure no wires get squished between the end-stop and the metal chassis. From the photos above, you can see I had some warping. This would have printed much better if I had a hood over the printer for the duration of the print This warping made it necessary to make some adjustments with a knife to make everything fit, and I used pieces o the brim and some acetone (drops via a screwdriver tip) to fill holes.
The fit was quite tight too. I then used my ABS juice in a spray bottle to lightly spray the surface to give it a nice shine. It didn't take away all of the lines from printing, but gave it a much nicer appearance. Good enough for 10 minutes of finishing. WARNING: you're playing with mains voltage if you assemble this. I give no warranty, take no responsibility, etc! if you're not licensed to work with mains voltage, you may want to get some one to do this that knows what they are doing!

This was drawn in onshape, and the drawing is public. If you search for me and/or 'NES-50 cover' in the public documents, you should find it.
If you make modifications or improve on it, please share and let me know!

description.text:
If you own a Leapfrog CreatR this little thing might save your print.
It will insure that the filament spool will stay in place on its rotative platform during the print. I just ruined a 8h39mn print in the very last minutes because the spool failed from the rotative platform resulting in no more filament feeding the extruder ! (see photo) And that's because the spool was having just few filament left.
Therefore it was not heavy enough to stay in place by itself .
Something the Leapfrog team should have think of ! Edited : I also uploaded version 1 because I don't have time to print and test V2, and because I'm sure V1 works well. Please tell me if V2 is high enough. I have a doubt here...
Photos are showing V1... V2 vs V1 should
  • use less filament
  • be stronger
  • take less time to print
  • be as efficient (not tested)
    • Edited October 15th 2013 :
    I uploaded a V2 version with a 13mm hole as requested by Rene (see comments) because it seems there is also a 13mm bolt CreatR version.
    Weird...
    Please visit http://www.reppersdelight.spacymen.com for more information.

Print with ABS or PLA.
Use support.
Mount it in the center of the filament pool rotative platform (see photo).

Here's a completely parametric air vent adapter I made a couple of years ago. I used to live in a double brick apartment block (cinder blocks for interior walls). As I was renting, I couldn't install a permanent air con and as I was on the top floor and the place had an iron roof, it was basically an oven in summer (Who am I kidding an Aussie summer turns just about any place into an oven) So I procured a portable air con. Issue was that the thickness of the cinder blocks meant that the window sills got in the way of putting the vent in the window correctly. Few hours designing and several more working out the math and I had this... then i moved out so never actually ended up making it. I recently saw someone post something similar and it reminded me of this, so here ya go have 1 that you can make any shape you want. It has been designed to ensure no restriction of air flow but that being said don't go setting up a 10cm pipe to got through a 1 cm gap (don't think that it would even fit on a printer bed) The parameters are as follows:
Input Pipes Diameter
How much lip is required to connect the input pipe to the adapter
How big a gap you want between the window frame and the window itself (ie the width of your plank of wood minus whatever's going to fit inside the frame)
mow mush lip is required for screws to attach to plank of wood.
how much you need to offset the pip to clear any obstacle like window sills ect (recommend playing with this a bit, generally you want one side to line up with the start of the window opening so you guarantee it wont hit anything)
how big a transition zone is required, this will determine how noisy it is but is restricted by how high you can print.
how far out do we need to go from the window before we can start the transition to the pipe
finally how thick we want the walls to be It will take all these to work out how wide the slot in the wood can be to still allow enough room for screws and then extrapolate from this and the desired pipe diameter how long the slot will need to be to accommodate the volume of air that the pipe can pass. we do this by splitting a circle in half and inserting a rectangle of the difference between the 2 openings in between area of rectangle = area of cross section of pipe - the area of the biggest circle we can fit in the window gap mins the screw lip either side. Though the code doesn't actually use a cube, it just draws 2 cylinders and hulls them so we get nice seems no matter what wacky numbers we end up with. then the opening is made by subtracting the thickness from all dimensions (designed to go inside pipe so cant go larger than diameter) Anyway, have fun. experiment with the variables to get your desired result

I really liked the idea of Supeso to build a street puzzle for his kids and wanted one for mine, too. :-) Since there were some minor details i would have liked to change, I redesigned his idea in openscad giving some of my thoughts into it. These were:

title: Cylinder Vase, Cup, and Bracelet Generator

description.text: Let your imagination run wild stacking cylinders. With essentially an infinite number of choices in the customizer you can be assured no one will have an object just like your's. By changing the dimensions you can make planters, trays, bud vases, pencil holders, bracelets, or drinking glasses. The simpler smaller objects make good demonstration pieces and will print quite quickly.

Run the customizer and choose your parameters and export the STL. Be careful to avoid large overhangs. It is quite possible to use the customizer to create something unprintable. When slicing specify no fill and no top layers for a vase.  For a bracelet, specify no fill and no top or bottom layers. You can often get away with only one perimeter, but if you want a better chance at water tightness or a stronger piece, add more perimeters.  Once you print it, be sure to upload a photo. I'm curious to see what people end up with. I have several other vase customizers with variations on this theme. Check out the "Derived from" to see the other versions.  
Note, Slic3r complains about the twist model, but it prints fine anyway.  Slic3r missed some surfaces of the stacked model, but it ended up making a nice basket weave pattern so it still looks nice.

title: Hellraiser Lament Configuration Jewellery Box Remix

description.text:
I started with Imirnman's Hellraiser Jewellry Box, but cut it up so that each side would print facing up, for slightly better detail quality. I used an Up Plus2 on Fine detail with Thin Wall setting enabled (important). Gluing it back together was fairly tricky. I had to tidy up the edges with a sharp knife to get it all to fit (my alignment notches didn't work very well) and then I used a lot of elastic bands to hold it while the glue dried. 
I sanded the sides for flatness after printing, then used gloss gold-coloured spray paint, sprayed lightly onto a flat piece of wood, then pressed the box sides onto the wood to pick up paint a bit at a time. If the paint is too wet, it will flow into the holes in the design. If you paint the sides before gluing, you have a chance to reprint any that get ruined by too much paint. It can be hard to hold the sides while painting if you do it this way - some blu-tac may help.
I recommend you use the drawers from Imirnman's design.

title: 12v Plug adapter for benchtop power supply

description.text: This will adapt a marine grade 12v plug to a bench top power supply. It allows me to test 12v car adapter circuits without climbing in and out of my car. I had originally intended to have the 12v plug mounted in my power supply, but I ran out of real estate, so an external adapter with a bit of extra cord was created. Plug: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00G3ZPYPC

I used 18g wire for the leads, and banana plugs for the connectors.    Solder on the wires to the plug, mount in the sleeve (you have to use long pliers or the like to get the nut to tighten).  Then feed the wires through the cap.  Leave a little slack in the sleeve, and then put a zip tie around the wire so it won't pull through.    Use glue (I used ABS/Acetone slurry) to seal the cap on.   Then attach the banana plugs.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement part for a South bend lathe model 9C that I just received, this part was worn out so made a replacement out of ABS PLA may be stronger. I made it as a single piece model printed in the orientation as in the stl file.
works like a new one, nice and firm no backlash at all. I will have other pieces for this same lathe, change gears, cross slide nut, top slide handle,
Plus whatever I need to replace because it is missing or worn out. My lathe was made between 1937 and 1940. Thread is 7/16 10 TPI ACME

Printer:

ORDBOT HADRON MODIFIED FLASHFORGE

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100 %

Notes: PUT SUPPORTS IN THE THREAD AND UNDER THE BOSS

FINISHING AND FITTING I drilled then tapped the grub screw hole later, and the hole for the locking pin. To clean the thread out of the nut cut a couple of grooves in the end of the screw to use as a tap. Once you get the screw started work it in and out about a half a turn each time until right through. then put a drop of oil on the thread and drive the screw back and forth over the length using a battery drill. The screw will become warm and help form the threads to the screw. You will find there are areas that are tight and loose because of un-even wear, you need to judge for yourself how hard you want it to be to turn, and how much backlash you will put up with.I am very happy with mine, good as new. You may find you will need to shim behind the dial as ther will be slack here also.

The reason I used the cross slide screw is that I do not have a tap for that thread.
I feel the thread is as accurate as can be printed, when you clean the thread out with the cross slide screw the plastic expands partially so you end up with a fairly tight fit. I shaped the end of the thread so that id would cut the thread in the plastic and not just try to dis-form the plastic

This is a test object for extrusion based systems that is quick to print and will exhibit a lot of ooze unless countermeasures are taken. I\'ve been working on anti-ooze for my Bowden based extrusion system (which has a lot of oozing if you don\'t do anything against it). Together with Nophead we\'ve had particularly good results:
http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2009/11/hacking-with-erik.html The latest version of my 3D-to-5D.php software solution checks whether a pull back is necessary. Segments that are very close to each other will not result in a pull back. If it\'s further apart, it has time to ooze more. Also, I don\'t want it to add too much to the build times. Other references:
  • Adrian\'s response when also trying pullback (again):
    http://blog.reprap.org/2009/11/end-to-ooze-ii.html
  • Nophead\'s RepRap blog post:
    http://blog.reprap.org/2009/11/end-to-ooze-and-support-material-found.html
  • Extruder valve
    http://blog.reprap.org/2008/08/extruder-valve.html

• Download.
  • Slice it in skeinforge.
    Make sure you turn of the towering feature, otherwise the model doesn\'t really exhibit much oozing.
    Faster travel speeds can mitigate oozing. Pulling back the filament also helps.
  • Print it.
    • The STL file is twice the dimensions that are listed in the CAD image.

Many bracelets exist already here on thingiverse (one of my favorites is MakeALot's: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7354), but most are rigid shapes. This design bends smoothly around the wrist and clasps in a secure, yet smooth and unobtrusive way. The intent is also to show how any bas relief design can be turned into a unique flexible bracelet. The pattern shown here is simply a pleasing combination of sinusoids. There are several levels of personalization available, depending on how much effort you want to put in. The easiest is to scale the file to fit your wrist (the current design has a circumference of 17.1cm with two pieces). Any number can be joined to form a larger circle. By adding M1 commands to the Gcode you can switch colors at different heights to highlight certain features (as shown). And finally, you can modify the OpenSCAD file to turn your own design into a segmented, flexible bracelet.

I use Multiply to print two of these at once.  The initial z-height must be well-calibrated and make sure that "infill begin rotation" is zero in the fill section of SF, so that the fill lines run the length of the bracelet for strength.  A single layer is meant to form the backbone of the bracelet, so if your layer thickness is vastly different than 0.3mm, you may have to adjust the T parameter in the scad file.  I'm not sure about PLA, but ABS has plenty of strength and flexibility to keep this bracelet from wearing out.
The base shape in this case was created in Matlab (wiggly.m), which will also probably run in Octave, though in either case you'll need to download surf2stl from the file exchange.  Feel free to modify this to a different mathematical shape, or start fresh from any other modeling approach.

description.text:
This is a project I build for the first Maker Faire in Germany (in Hannover): The Raspberry Pi Glass (or wearable Raspberry Pi) Most of the project is printable with a 3D printer, I used gold colored PLA to get a retro futuristic look. In addition to the printable parts you will need:
  • A Raspberry Pi ;-)
  • SainSmart 1.8 ST7735R TFT LCD Module: http://bit.ly/sainsmartdisplay
  • The kernel module for this display: http://www.whence.com/rpi/
  • 2 small plastic or glass lenses
  • Small Bluetooth keyboard: http://www.ebay.de/itm/111079678580
  • Bluetooth dongle: http://www.ebay.de/itm/290762845726
  • USB Powerbank: http://bit.ly/powergenusb
  • ~40 brass screws M3x20 (some has to be shortened)
  • 1 brass screw M3x30
  • 2 brass screws M4x20
  • ~50 brass nuts M3
  • 4 brass nuts M4
  • 2 self tapping screws (must fit through the holes of the Raspberry Pi)
  • Artificial or real leather
  • A cheap wristwatch
  • Acrylic glass (fluorescent for a nicer look)
  • 2 5mm UV LEDs and two matching resistors
  • A small switch
    • You will also need some small parts like rivets, cables, USB plugs etc.

I made a video about how it works in detail (in German language only, sorry):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WTB9G9G9lP0

title: Halo 4 Helmet Full Size ( Small child )

description.text:
This model is now DEPRECATED by That means DON'T print this one, print one of the following! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158120 - Adult A
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225884 - Medium B
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:181491 - Child C Information below is historical. Update 11 Added some final pics of assembled with new chin print ( as previous had print error, model was good ) I consider this size model complete now. All further efforts will be to scale up, tweak, reprint, which I will publish as a separate "thing" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:138405 Note image of helmet being worn, has no internal padding or positioning, so is effective just balanced on the head. Update 10 Added part model images so you can see construction Update 9 Added final pieces ( yeah! ), roof, peak ( left and right ) Still printing my way through. Also added a backfan version which has the circular piece cut out and an insert model, which I have printed in clear, and am playing with led sources. WIll update pics as final pieces are printed. Update 8 Added left and right temple. Finding that tension pins holes are loose on the new shiny pins I have, not a big deal as they are for location only, parts will be bonded together in the end. Will resize when I do an adult size version. Update 7 Adding images as I print pieces. Will be making a new top fan with clear insert and rgb led. Current front chin had a print error, due to print lifting, but model is fine. Also have not yet cleaned the joint surfaces so will be a tighter fit. Update 6 Added RearTopSide pieces.
Update 5 Better encapsulation of pins in chin front piece. Update 4 Fixed better encapsulation of pins in Jowl pieces. Update 3. Definitely coming out small child size. Its going to be close for my 4 year old! Will continue at this scale to fix all the matters arising until I have a full print, then will rescale for adult, fix all the pins sizes and republish. Assembled image shows existing pieces connected, though I have not sanded the joint surface yet, so it will go tighter. Update 2. Things are printing well, but it looks like this will more likely fit my son than me. Once I am done, I will make an adult size version as well. Also have no idea what to do for the visor yet. Update 1. As the chin print delaminated in the same place twice, I have resliced to three separate pieces. Will stop slicing the model now, until I have enough prints to prove methodology. ORIGINAL POST Working on full size pieces to print on my replicator 2. Uses 1/8 x 3/4 tension pins for location of pieces to each other. Will publish as I print, so expect this to take weeks as I iterate, and the chin is a 8 hour print! I suspect the first one will not be big enough for me, and too big for my son, so likely will rescale once I have one fully assembled. ( note if you just rescale the STL's the tension pin holes will be wrong. ) Until I have one fully assembled, then I will not know if the slicing allows easy removal ( by unlatching the chin piece for example ) so I expect to go through alot of printing hours before its good start to end. As well as building in the latch mounts when it is evident where they need to go, and possibly mounting a fan in the back if there is room. Note this large print of the chin has a delamination error, as can be seen half way up the model. Have tried slicing higher, and got the same error in the same place, so makerware likely doesn't like getting the slice / support quite right. I will be reslicing to get a more successful print. All part of the process I guess. Derived from http://hce.halomaps.org/index.cfm?fid=6127

description.text:
Baby Bottle Feeder Toolhead I'm using this on a industrial robot to automatically feed my 2-month-old. I thought it was an interesting experiment. And it helps me to stay productive with other things.
  • fits the toolhead mount of a Fanuc LR Mate 200iC industrial robot
  • Clip diameter is 37mm.
  • Made to hold a 100ml baby bottle (Tombik TMBK0458).
    Leave a comment if it fits other bottles!

Programming the robot
I programmed the robot to slowly enter the crib and feed for ~ 20 minutes. It slowly tilts the bottle to make sure it is emptied completely. I can send you the program on request. For security reasons, I advise you to stay in the same room during the feeding procedure. I also have a kill switch ready, just in case.

DISCLAIMER: THIS IS NOT A REAL PRODUCT
Don't use it to feed a baby!
The Robot Baby Feeder Toolhead is a conceptual object. It's part of a project investigating how our children might become a generation of robotic natives. Please see the project page for more.
Rubber Coating I spray painted my model with Plasti Dip rubber coating. Improves the grip and eases cleaning.

This is a bracket for positioning the z-stop microswitch on the frame of the prussa i3. This is designed for the 6mm plywood frame, but it could be easily adapted for a different thickness of frame.

Just print out the part, add two m3 nuts and two m3 screws, then hot glue on the micro-switch. The bracket can be clamped in any position along the main (wood) panel of the prussa frame. Re positioning is as easy as loosening the screws a bit then sliding up or down.

description.text: Sand Scoop 3

A simple sign with a hole for a magnet in the back.
Edit the the name and dimensions using the Customizer link below
Attaching a magnet Either glue or (if sufficiently tight) heat the part with a heat gun to insert the magnet

Every player has their own preference for pick thickness, shape and material.  This design features tapered thickness, variable corner radii and optional hole for hanging on a keyring, necklace, etc.  
UPDATE:  Added a second STL file, modified with a center hole and a notch so it can be clipped onto a cord, whammy bar, belt loop or wherever it's convenient.  You can even use it as a baggie tie!

Due to a rounding error I am working on fixing for the next version, you will have to move the object onto the platform before printing. It may look like it's on the plate, but it's slightly off, and this may affect printing if you don't zero it. Makerware warns about this, other slicers may not. About the variables:
Default values are optimized for nylon. The picks I have made out of Taulman's 618 and 645 are capable of handling extreme shredding and abuse that would destroy ABS or PLA in no time. If you do print with ABS or PLA, reduce tip height to around 0.5 and bevel to around 0.5 or 0.75, or else your pick will be very stiff. For a flat pick with no taper, set bevel to zero. Actual height of final object is determined by tip height and bevel angle. If height variable is too low, there will be flats at the thick parts, and the final object will not sit flat on the build platform.
Material PLA.

title: Folgertech Prusa i3 2020 Y-Axis Upgrade (Openbuilds V-Slot Rail System)

description.text: This is a Y-Axis upgrade to the Folgertech Prusa i3 2020 Variant, however it should work with any 2020 rail printer, and could be adapted to an all-thread framed printer with a few additional brackets. It replaces the cheap linear bearings and 8mm rods with an Openbuilds V-Slot Gantry and rail system. Noise reduction is huge with this upgrade, accuracy is increased and overall stiffness of the Y-Axis is also increased. This system is up and running on my printer along with a few others (although there are a few variation in the assembly). This version of the upgrade can use a full length rial (500mm) which should allow an increased Y movement of 100mm for a total build length of 300mm. This can also be cut down to a more standard length (~420mm) for a conventional 200mm Y movement. At this point I am not writing assembly instructions as it is pretty straight forward, I have provided a link to a Imgur Album showing detailed photos of the build. This is a work in progress so there are variations of the build (with-in the album) so please keep this in mind when looking through the photos. http://imgur.com/a/GQs2U Edit: I have now provide an additional endstop mount V-4, it has 2.5mm holes and will require they be tapped to M3, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1214608 I have provided a BOM and a Hole Layout to use the original FT ALM Bed Support. There is a standard and long version of the belt tensioner. You can checkout before and after videos here: Before: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XsJfkrgD0tM Note: the noise you hear in this video is from the X-Axis (Upgrade in the works). After: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4HJPyrFLzk Bench Test: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CWApRvskVB0 Edit: QuadBert had designed a very nice bed support to go between the FT Alm plate and the OB gantry plate. I looks great and adds just enough stiffness and height to make a better bed setup. Check out his bed support here, and don't forget to fool and check his other designs as well: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1266958 Edit: When mounting the idler pulley assembly I used a standard M5 x 8mm SHCS, I did tap the holes prior to installing the screws though, OB recommends these self-tapping screws: http://openbuildspartstore.com/self-tapping-screw/ However, I bet you could find something suitable at the big box stores or your local hardware store!?!? Edit: 12-11-2017 I've been asked about the QTY (4) 6mm spacers and how they work with my current setup so I thought I'd elaborate on that a bit. I use the spacer in-lieu-of a the 3D Printed mounts like the ones in the previous photos. What I did was simply remove the Printed Mounts and replace them with the spacer and the original aluminum bed plate. There is a PDF of the holes layout required to use the Alm plate only without the Printed mounts. QuadBert has a set of mounts on thingi (see link below) whish work along with the aluminum plate, they should work great and would eliminate the need of the 6mm spacers. Hope this clear up and confusion surrounding the need of the 6mm spacer ;-) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1266958

Printer:

Folgertech Prusa i3 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

Varies

Notes: Rotate parts and add support when needed.

Y-Carriage Parts List (1) V-Slot Gantry Set Plate​: 20mm ​- 80m​m (Un​ivers​al) Wheel​: Delri​n Sol​id V ​Wheel​s (look at the bundles) (4) 6mm spacers (1) V-Slot™ Linear Rail Size: 20mm ​x 80m​m Lengt​h: 500mm Color​: Silve​r (1) Precision Shim - 10x5x1mm (for idle pulley bearings) (2) 5x13x4 (FLANGED) Metal Shielded Bearing F695-ZZ (1) 20 GT2 20 tooth Pulley (1.5M) (5 Feet) GT2 Timing Belt Misc: screws, tie wraps, etc... You can either buy more or use the 5mm T-Nut from the SK8s...the short screw that FT sent are the perfect length to mount it with the brackets I used.

comments.text: Even a good lm8uu with hardened steel precision chrome rods, which have tighter tolerances than stainless introduce a lot of slop.  Whether it matters on an fdm printer is questionable.  You do however get a lot of sag in an lm8uu setup at anything longer than 400mm, so if you must stick with linear bearing guides I'd go with lm10uu.  This setup is very smooth on my cnc using makerslide, which is very similar, even with all the carbon fiber and aluminum dust flying around.  The increased diameter of the wheel surface over the guide is likely why.  Think of 40 .5mm balls rolling over an imperfect surface compared to a 22mm wheel with sealed bearings.  The technical advantage is a much stiffer y-axis/build surface.  Hope this helps.
comments.author: Toranado3D

comments.text: Sorry, but I'm not an engineer so I'm not sure from a purely technical standpoint what the advantages are over rods and linear bearings.
