description.text: This is designed to work with the RoBo3D printers, the hole for the DI is made for DI with mounting diameter of 8mm. It has two holes for magnets size 6x5mm. Holes may need to be drilled out a bit.

comments.text: what is the purpose of this dial ?
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: It helps level the bed to the extruder carriage by giving the dial indicator a stable connection to the X-axis smooth rod supports.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: Never had to use one to level my printer.
comments.author: Aienan

comments.text: I should use calibrate rather than level. The bed does not need to be perfectly level, instead the extruder carriage needs to be parallel to the build surface. With the spring levelers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:125626), and some patience the Robo 3D bed (without auto leveling) can be brought within .002" of parallel relatively easily. This gives a consistent layer height no matter where on the bed it is printed.

Now I can consider this project finished. The original stand has been used with all kind of computers, tablets, laptops and even notebooks. This last version includes some minor details that will make your device fit perfectly avoiding the risk of falling down the stand. You have to cut (using the DXF file) or print (using the STL files) 2 arms and 2 supports. The vitamins needed are the same than in previous versions, but I now include nut caps created by jspark:
  • 3 x 20cm (or longer) M8 threaded bars
  • 12 x M8 nuts
  • 12 x M8 Washers (optional)
  • 6 x Closed M8 nut caps
  • 6 x Open M8 nut caps
    • We replaced all the MK2 in the office by MK3 as we found that some devices (specially the thinner MacBooks Air) could fall from the stand. That's not fun, one of these machines costs as much as a compatible kidney. In addition I also include DXF files that will allow your stand to be processed in your favorite laser cutter. I strongly advice Acrylic, 8 or 10mm for this stand in that case. And orange. I love orange. A video with all the steps is also available. If you would like to support my work you can buy a laptop stand in Spitni

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 ION

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

30%

Notes: If you use ABS filament, as this is a model of certain length, I advice the use of a 6mm brim around in order to reduce warping. The use of Lacquer is also advised. PLA and other filaments as Nylon should work perfectly.

description.text:
Build volume: 150x150x145 mm
Print/travel speed: >150 mm/s Approximate building cost: up to $250 (acrylic case, 6 mm plywood also okay). Most likely you will not find a heater with apropriate size (182x202 mm), I use aluminium alloy plate with 12v 100watt silicone heater pad (180x180 mm) glued to the bollom of the plate. Marlin 1.0.2 firware configured for this printer: https://github.com/robotsrulz/Marlin I didn't work on full BOM and assembly instructions, it's mostly the same as in original project although you will need more short hex head bolts and nyloc nuts for rails and pulleys. If you have any difficulties assemblyng the projects drop me a message, I will answer shortly. Test print video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sY8cQZ5xOEQ Complete printer assembly (STEP / IGES, Fusion 360, DesignSpark Mechanical): https://grabcad.com/library/signum-cxy150r2-2 Other STL files which could be used for building the printer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1165682/#files

I got fed up trying to set my Z Probe to the correct height using the large nuts and locking washers it came with. Every time I thought I'd gotten it right my nozzle would attempt some bed diving.
This holder makes it easy to make fine adjustments using a screwdriver. 
This is my second design the first had a spring above the Z Probe holder and the inside top of bracket. No longer necessary  using the longer bolt and a locknut at the bottom.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes: I printed the bracket on it's back and the Z Probe holder top on the bed (upside down), this reduces the support needed.

Once printed I sanded the post behind the Z Probe holder so it slid easily inside the bracket. I drilled and taped the hole on the Z Probe holder post, I'm using 4M bolt. Additional parts
1 x 4Mx50mm Bolt
1 x 4M Nylon Locknut
2 x 4M washers
This was designed using Vectorworks 15, software now exports STL files
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4f9UCZCsMSs
